Author: jl777c#5810
Content: digishield is back to using only targetA, unless RST is over. in that case it uses 7/8 of the targetA for the blocks that had RST active

Author: miraculu#8334
Content: Please what version of verushash does smart chains use.  I really need to know if it's asic resistant.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: 1.0 ,  no known asic but it is FPGA dominated

Author: miraculu#8334
Content: Please is there a way to make a smart chain asic/FPGA resistant?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Kind of impossible ,  any chain that is profitable enough eventually will have a bitstream made for it .

Author: ComputerGenie 游놊游낖游닉#7004
Content: chains with good utility don't need "asic/FPGA resistance"

Author: miraculu#8334
Content: I have a targeted audience that don't have access to asic/FGPA and I'll like the community to be part of the block producers.

Author: miraculu#8334
Content: Staking would have been the solution, but the docs says it's shouldn't be used in production.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @miraculu  cost of low end FPGA is cheaper than low end  current generation GPU and  medium end CPU

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: https://www.hashaltcoin.com/en/batches/14

Author: Gordon Komodo#7477
Content: you can also do 10%pow and 90% staking or other ratio variation

Author: miraculu#8334
Content: @polycryptoblog  Thanks , never knew they were that cheap.

Author: miraculu#8334
Content: @Gordon Komodo  is staking production ready?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: VerusPoS you could say is,  even pos64 is being used on live chains

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: But still new technology so just proceed with caution

Author: Gordon Komodo#7477
Content: zexo and ourc are both ecosystem projects that enabled staking as well as veruscoin of course

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @miraculu @polycryptoblog there is a version dubbed "verushash1.1" that smart chains can use right now

Author: Alright#0419
Content: it's basically verushash1.0 but with a few tricks to slow down FPGA development for it

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Joker made it, he'd be able to explain. It's not a good long term solution for a chain though. Is basically security through obscurity

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Did not know that ,  will have to ask him about it

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Yes, the verushash1.1 is verushash 1 with a random seed, so there are no FPGA or even GPU miners for it, as it never got used on any real chain. The code was all there in the Verus merge for sapling, but the algo was not activated so I added the code nneded to use it as a3rd algo option.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: -ac_algo=verushash11

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: It also works with verusPoS and PoS64, but PoS64 is a little weird on verushash, it works, but blocktimes can be a bit crazy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Might be something to study but I would not recommend using that on a new production mainnet of any coin

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: its been tested plenty of times.. I starrted at least 100 chains using that algo while trying toi get pos64 working on it

Author: Alright#0419
Content: we've used it on many CFEK chains. Works as intended

Author: miraculu#8334
Content: @Alright  and @blackjok3r  thank you very much. I'll check it out.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I am sure blackjoker+Alright have done good work on that hash variant. It's just that most people using it aren't going to realize that if it were profitable, an FPGA could mine it very effectively, it's just that no financial target has ever appeared to bitstream devs. Why is somebody using the function, and do they realize they may be that first target of this new variant? People just need to understand what it's limitations are

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: most people making new smart chains don't know enough to decide between Equihash (N,K) variants and this, so we guide them to what we think is best for most situations. I am trying to think of a situation where I would recommend verushash1.1 to a consulting client, and I can't think of one

Author: Laviathon -bcmonster.com#0462
Content: I have been having problems with linux and ./komodod crashing ... what version should I be on or do I need some new command line... all the KMD asset chains are fine... Just KMD

Author: Laviathon -bcmonster.com#0462
Content:
komodod: /home/kmdmonster/komodo/depends/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/share/../include/boost/thread/pthread/recursive_mutex.hpp:118: void boost::recursive_mutex::unlock(): Assertion `!pthread_mutex_unlock(&m)' failed.
Aborted (core dumped)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Laviathon -bcmonster.com how large is your KMD wallet.dat?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: also, that is usually a race condition that happens very rarely, if you try again, does it happen consistently?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: if your system is heavily loaded, it's more likely as well

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: if the problem is persistent, starting a new wallet.dat and importing any necessary keys might make it less likely. It's a real bug, but nobody has been able to fix it. Also happens in Zcash and all Zcash coins, but is only triggered very rarely. Usually I see it on an overloaded system, and trying again works

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @zawy https://twitter.com/matthew_d_green/status/1165403130756042752

Author: Laviathon -bcmonster.com#0462
Content: @dukeleto it only happens on kmd for example I have hush running in the same server,   No issues.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Laviathon -bcmonster.com KMD does things no other chain does, such as interest, so it might only happen on KMD
